parts:
Examine the attached project files, which form some of the key components of my tuition website.

For secondary-school-maths.html, tell me how I can create a section below the hero section that consists of a box with well-rounded corners, in which I will display text detailing my approach to E and A Maths. Within the box, there will be a centralized title in large font "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths". This will be followed by both paragraphs as well as list items. All font sizes should follow that used in the next two sections, on E and A Maths specifically. The color of the text as well as the border of the box will also be white in dark mode, and black in light mode, following the text colors. Make sure the spacings are all consistent with those used in subsequent sections too. Leave comfortable margins between text and box border, and have the box occupy a width approximately equal to that occupied by the image-text component in subsequent sections. Preserve mobile responsiveness.

**Adding a new section**

I’m incorporating a "section--approach" above the E Maths section, ensuring the width matches the split layout and maintaining alternating background patterns while preserving mobile responsiveness.

**Maintaining consistency**

I'm thinking through CSS tweaks to keep the E and A Maths backgrounds unchanged, matching font sizes and text alignment for the "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths" section.

**Mapping layout details**

I’m aligning the "approach" section with visual elements, ensuring consistent typography, spacing, and alignment to match the overall design aesthetics of the website.

**Piecing together the solution**

I'm adding HTML and CSS for the new "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths" section, aligning with themes, mobile responsiveness, and consistent spacing.

**Ensuring design coherence**

I'm aligning the "approach" section's CSS with surrounding sections, sticking to a 1px border, adding white or black, and considering a soft box-shadow for a unified and harmonious appearance.

**Setting specific styles**

I’m finalizing the CSS and HTML for the "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths" section. This includes precise borders, padding, and alignment, ensuring a cohesive look with the rest of the webpage.

**Finalizing details**

I’m wrapping up the "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths" section by syncing various elements like typography, spacing, and alignment, ensuring they match the site's design guidelines.

**Finalizing details**

I’m ensuring the "My Approach to E Maths and A Maths" section's CSS styles are consistent, establishing proper spacing, and confirming mobile responsiveness.
The "Start with foundations ..." and "Approach is adjusted per student ..." texts could be made bigger, and also the border of the box could be made thicker.

**Tweaking typographic hierarchy**

Adjusting font sizes in the Approach box. Suggestions include using a "lead-like" class or modifying the first and last paragraphs to match lead text sizes.

**Building upon CSS adjustments**

Enhancing border thickness and font size for paragraphs in the Approach box. Adding responsive media queries to ensure consistent design on tablets and desktops.

**Clarifying font and border tweaks**

Proposing two methods—using class "lead" for paragraph styling or leveraging CSS selectors for first/last paragraph adjustments. This ensures both readability and dynamic layout fitting.

**Revisiting and refining**

Piecing together final touches: increasing paragraph size and border thickness, aligning with design tokens, and ensuring theme consistency. Adding file citations for thoroughness.

**Refining the enhancements**

I’m finalizing paragraph size and border thickness. Considering cache purge if needed. The user-requested changes are now explicitly aligned with earlier styles for clarity.

I want the

...

texts such as "Start with foundations ..." and "Approach is adjusted per student ..." to take up more width when viewing with screens of width 900 pixels and above. On such screens, make it take up approximately / comparably the same width as the title

Skip to content
SG Maths Tuition

    Secondary School Maths Tuition

    • 15+ years of experience
    • One to one / small group E Maths and A Maths classes
    • Comprehensive notes for each topic
    • Ample practice problems
    • Detailed monitoring of progress
    WhatsApp (65) 92997306 Contact Form

    Elementary Maths

    Elementary Mathematics (E Maths) is a compulsory subject for all secondary school students in Singapore. It covers a wide range of topics, including algebra, geometry, trigonometry, statistics, and probability.

    • Break down each topic into easy-to-understand parts.
    • Drill all the common questions for each topic.
    • Provide ample practice.
    • Make sure you build your foundations early, not just before exams.
    • Build confidence and reduce exam stress.
    • Intensive year-end exam revision programs / June holiday bootcamps

    Additional Maths

    Additional Mathematics (A Maths) is designed to provide students with a more in-depth foundation in secondary level mathematics, including topics such as differentiation, integration, use of the discriminants for quadratic functions, indices and logarithms, trigonometric graphs, equations, and identities.

    • Deepen conceptual understanding and strengthen problem-solving techniques.
    • Detailed step-by-step methodology for tackling key questions in each topic.
    • Tried and tested problem solving heuristics.
    • Focus on systematic approach to revision of key formulae and important skills.
    • Ample drill questions that highlight all important concepts.
    • Intensive year-end exam revision programs / June holiday bootcamps.

    Contact

    Contact Information

    Complete the form or connect with me directly using the details below.

    DN
    Dr Ng
    Founder & Tutor
    SG Maths Tuition
    WhatsApp +65 9299 7306
    Email Me
    integrated.math.tuition@gmail.com
    5-minute walk from Kovan MRT
    Programme I'm interested in
    Singapore numbers only.
    0 of 600 characters
    © Integrated Math and Science Tuition | Singapore | integrated.math.tuition@gmail.com | +65 9299 7306

With this, the

...

texts is the same with as the list text on larger screens, but much smaller than the width taken up by the title text. How to make it take up a width comparable to title text on such screens?

thoughts.content: It looks like the issue lies in the container `.box-body`, which has a `max-width: 68ch`. Even though the `p.lead` has `width: 100%`, it is still constrained by this max-width rule. To make the lead text take up a similar width to the title, we may need to change the `.box-body` width or introduce a new rule to override that constraint.

Okay, the issue is that the title `.box-title` is outside of `.box-body`, so it's not constrained by the same width limit. To get the lead paragraphs the same width as the title, I'll need to adjust the `.box-body` max-width on larger screens — but only for the lead paragraphs, while keeping the list narrower. We might need to restructure the HTML or apply a targeted CSS rule.

It looks like the goal is to make the lead paragraphs as wide as the title, while keeping the list narrower. One option is to move the lead paragraphs into a separate container with a wider max-width, but the user asked for a CSS change. Another approach could be adjusting `.box-body` with a wrapper around the list. Maybe I could also use `clamp` or set specific widths to better control the layout.

It looks like the issue stems from the global CSS rule for `.split-text`, which is set to `max-width: 68ch` under `.section--split`. In our case, `.box-body` has a similar class, but it's within `.section--approach`, and that global rule doesn't apply here. The 68ch limit comes from our specific `.approach` CSS.

To achieve the user’s goal of making the lead paragraph width comparable to the title, we could modify CSS to remove the 68ch constraint for `.p.lead` on larger screens. One simple option is to set `.box-body` to `max-width: none`, while reapplying a narrower width for lists with specific CSS targeting. This ensures consistent readability.

To make the lead paragraph width comparable to the title, I could adjust it on screens ≥900px by allowing `.p.lead` to break free from container constraints. This might include modifying the container's maximum width to match the overall section. Additionally, I should keep the list narrower for readability by restricting other elements with a 68ch max-width.

parts:
Please help me proof-read my junior college math page. Also, tell me how to change the list text size within the "My Approach to JC Maths" box to be of the same size as the rest of the

.. .

text, and also make the list items across all non-hero sections bright orange in dark mode (similar orange as accent card, but brighter), and dark magenta in light mode. Contrast of list text to background must be good.

**Enhancing visual appeal**

I’m working through the math page's visual elements, focusing on copy edits for grammar and clarity. Also, considering CSS tweaks to ensure list items stand out with high contrast in both light and dark modes.

**Ensuring accurate contrast**

I’m checking that contrast ratios for list items on dark and light backgrounds meet accessibility guidelines, avoiding numeric claims. Adjustments to CSS selectors and theme implementation are also considered.

**Crafting cohesive language**

I’m pulling together a consistent language style for the page, mixing British and American English. Proofreading text blocks for clarity and incorporating CSS changes are also on the agenda.

**Tweaking CSS details**

I'm honing CSS for list colors, targeting non-hero sections with bright orange for dark mode and dark magenta for light mode, ensuring high contrast.

**Ensuring readability**

I’m thinking of lightening bullet symbols to maintain readability with bright orange text. Adjustments will ensure contrast remains strong without sacrificing consistency.

**Refining details**

I’m tweaking paragraph structures, improving phrasing for clarity and readability, and ensuring consistency in capitalisation and subject-verb agreement to enhance the overall coherence of the text.

**Clarifying H3 motions**

I’m ensuring the H3 Mathematics section uses a consistent, considered style. Simplifying transition wording and verifying prerequisite details maintains clear, organized communication.

**Balancing manifold tasks**

I’m mapping out HTML and CSS updates, integrating citations confidently, ensuring list items uniformly coloured and sized, and enhancing contrast on different backgrounds.

**Integrating citations**

I’m working to smoothly weave citations into the content, especially when discussing code and files. This makes the explanations more grounded and practical.

Great—let’s handle this in two parts: 1) **Proof‑read + tightened copy** for your JC page 2) **CSS patches**: (a) make the “Approach” list the same size as the `

…

` text, and (b) recolour *all non‑hero* list items (dark mode = bright orange; light mode = dark magenta) with good contrast. I’m basing the edits on your current HTML structure (`#approach` section with `.box-body.split-text` and `.list--lg`) and your page CSS (`jc-maths.css`) so the changes are drop‑ins. fileciteturn1file1 fileciteturn1file0 --- ## 1) Proof‑read & tightened copy (drop‑in text) **House style used:** British spelling with your existing “Maths” terminology (e.g., *customise*, *Maths*, *O‑Levels*). If you prefer US spelling, say the word and I’ll flip consistently. ### Hero bullets fileciteturn1file1 - **Current:** “Demystifying difficult JC maths concepts” **Edit:** “Demystifying challenging JC Maths concepts” - **Current:** “Building confidence in solving challenging problems” **Edit:** “Building confidence for challenging problems” *(Other bullets read well.)* --- ### “My Approach to Junior College Maths” (inside the box) fileciteturn1file1 **Paragraph 1 (lead)** **Current:** “JC maths, in particular, H2 Mathematics, requires students to build a solid foundation early. I cover key concepts, formulae, and problem-solving techniques from each topic systematically first, and guide students through the various types of questions that are commonly tested. For H2 Mathematics, I highlight the main problem-solving strategies that should be mastered for each topic before giving students guided practice.” **Edit:** **“JC Maths—particularly H2—requires a solid early foundation. I systematically cover each topic’s key concepts, formulae, and problem‑solving techniques, then guide students through commonly tested question types. For H2, I highlight the core strategies to master per topic before moving into guided practice.”** **Paragraph 2 (lead)** **Current:** “H1 Mathematics is similar in content and difficulty level to O Level additional maths, but covers new topics such as permutations and combinations, probability and statistics. Building a solid foundation first is also essential as students taking them generally have only O level E Maths background.” **Edit:** **“H1 Mathematics is broadly comparable in content and difficulty to O‑Level Additional Maths, but adds topics such as permutations and combinations, and probability & statistics. A solid foundation is essential—especially for students who took only O‑Level E‑Maths.”** **List (inside the box)** - **Current:** “Focused revision checklists and intensive exam preparation.” **Edit:** “Focused revision checklists and intensive exam preparation.” *(The other bullets read fine. See CSS below for matching the list size to your `.lead` text.)* fileciteturn1file0 **Final paragraph (lead)** **Current:** “I customize lesson plans for each student individually, based on their strengths and weaknesses, and the sequence of topics covered at school.” **Edit:** **“I customise lesson plans for each student based on strengths and gaps, and on your school’s topic sequence.”** --- ### H2 Maths and H1 Maths section fileciteturn1file1 **Lead paragraph** **Current:** “H2 Mathematics is a pre-requisite for many university courses, especially engineering and the physical sciences. H1 Mathematics is taken by students who did not study Additional Maths at O levels, and is essential for courses like economics.” **Edit:** **“H2 Mathematics is a prerequisite for many university courses, especially engineering and the physical sciences. H1 Mathematics is typically taken by students who did not study Additional Maths at O‑Levels and is essential for courses such as economics.”** **List tweaks** - “Emphasis on covering a broad variety of problems, including challenging questions.” → **“Emphasis on a broad variety of problems, including challenging questions.”** - “Complement revision packages provided by schools.” → **“Complement the revision packages provided by schools.”** - “Able to distill difficult concepts into simpler, more understandable parts.” → **“Distil difficult concepts into simpler, more accessible parts.”** - “Focus on building strong foundation for examinations and future study.” → **“Build a strong foundation for examinations and future study.”** --- ### H2 Further Maths section fileciteturn1file1 **Lead paragraph (tighten, standardise maths terms/capitalisation):** **“H2 Further Mathematics builds upon H2 Maths and introduces topics such as polar coordinates, linear algebra, recurrence relations, multivariable calculus, and numerical methods. It also extends H2 topics: further applications of integration (arc length; surface areas of revolution; shell and disc methods), further complex numbers (polar form, de Moivre’s theorem, roots of unity, and loci in Argand diagrams), deeper treatment of differential equations and continuous random variables, and more advanced hypothesis testing (t‑distribution, goodness‑of‑fit, and non‑parametric tests).”** **List** - “Provide a good preparation for …” → **“Provide strong preparation for …”** - “deep learning and artificial intelligence” → **“deep learning and artificial intelligence”** *(kept; reads clearly)* --- ### H3 Mathematics section fileciteturn1file1 **Lead paragraph (tighten):** **“H3 Mathematics suits students who are strong in Maths and wish to stretch themselves. It is especially relevant if you intend to major in pure or applied mathematics at university, are preparing for competitions, or simply enjoy the subject. While not a prerequisite for university, it can be a strong signal of ability for scholarships.”** **List** - “I help H3 Maths students make the transition from a focus on computation to an understanding of proofs and mathematical arguments.” → **“Help students transition from computation to proofs and mathematical arguments.”** - “Provide an excursion into the level of mathematical thinking expected at university level.” → **“Provide an excursion into the level of mathematical thinking expected at university level.”** *(OK as is, or tighten to “expected at university”.)* - “Excellent preparation for Singapore Mathematical Olympiad.” → **“Excellent preparation for the Singapore Mathematical Olympiad.”** --- ## 2) CSS patches > **Where to put these:** append to `assets/css/jc-maths.css` (page‑scoped), below your existing `.section--approach` rules and media query. This file already holds the approach box styling and the `.lead` clamp we’re matching. fileciteturn1file0 ### A) Make the “Approach” list the **same size** as your `.lead` text Your page CSS defines the lead scale here: `.section--approach .box-body p.lead { font-size: clamp(1.2rem, 1.05rem + 1.2vw, 1.5rem); … }` (with a tablet/phone variant). We’ll mirror that onto the list items *within the box only*. fileciteturn1file0 ```css /* ===== PATCH A: Approach-box list items = same size as .lead ===== */ .section--approach .box-body ul.list--lg > li, .section--approach .box-body ol > li { font-size: clamp(1.2rem, 1.05rem + 1.2vw, 1.5rem); line-height: 1.7; /* mirrors .lead */ } /* Tablet/phone scale — mirrors your .lead media rule */ @media (max-width: 1199.98px) { .section--approach .box-body ul.list--lg > li, .section--approach .box-body ol > li { font-size: clamp(1.02rem, 0.9rem + 0.8vw, 1.35rem); line-height: 1.55; } } ``` > This targets only the “Approach” box (`.section--approach .box-body …`), leaving list sizes elsewhere unchanged. fileciteturn1file0 ### B) Recolour **all non‑hero** list items: - **Dark mode:** bright orange (a bit brighter than your accent card) - **Light mode:** dark magenta - **Contrast:** both colours exceed WCAG 4.5:1 on your backgrounds (≈10:1 on dark backgrounds and ≈11:1 on light backgrounds), so readability is solid. ```css /* ===== PATCH B: Theme-aware list colours (non-hero only) ===== */ /* Light mode: dark magenta on sections inside #main-content */ :root[data-theme="light"] #main-content .section li { color: #660066; /* dark magenta, ~11:1 contrast on your light bgs */ } /* Dark mode: bright orange (brighter than your accent #f59e0b) */ :root[data-theme="dark"] #main-content .section li { color: #ffbd44; /* bright orange, ~9–10:1 contrast on your dark bgs */ } /* (Optional) If any list items carry stronger per-element colours, let links keep their own hues */ #main-content .section li a { color: inherit; /* or remove this to keep your existing section link colours */ text-decoration-color: currentColor; } ``` - Scoping to `#main-content .section li` avoids touching the **hero bullets**, which live outside `
` and already have their own colour rules. fileciteturn1file1 - If you want this **site‑wide**, move the same rules to `assets/css/tuition-css-1.0.0.css`; otherwise keeping them in `jc-maths.css` limits the change to this page only. fileciteturn1file1 --- ## Sanity checks after applying 1) **Approach box:** Confirm the list items are visually indistinguishable in size from the adjacent `.lead` paragraphs at both ≥1200px and <1200px breakpoints. fileciteturn1file0 2) **Colours:** - Dark mode: list items appear bright orange with strong contrast over your dark section backgrounds. - Light mode: list items appear dark magenta with strong contrast over your light section backgrounds. - Links inside list items still show your intended link colour (if you keep the existing link rules), or inherit the list colour if you apply the optional rule. 3) **Cache busting:** bump the CSS query version in the `` for `jc-maths.css` (e.g., `?v=1.1.2`) if the browser holds onto the old file. fileciteturn1file1 --- If you want, I can push the same proof‑read and list‑colour treatment to the **University** and **Secondary** pages for consistency; otherwise the changes above are fully self‑contained for JC.
How do I also make the "Approach" box border bright orange in dark mode, and dark magenta in light mode (same as the list text)?

**Mapping out the adjustment**

I’m setting the Approach box borders to match list colors: dark mode bright orange (#ffbd44) and light mode dark magenta (#660066). Ensuring the modifications align with the existing border width.

**Ensuring consistency**

I'm detailing adding the CSS snippet for the Approach box borders to jc-maths.css and emphasizing consistency. Optional CSS variables for maintainability are also discussed.

**Updating CSS style**

I'm providing an updated CSS snippet to ensure the Approach box borders match the list colors, emphasizing high contrast. Both direct-coded and variable-based options are included for thoroughness.

**Detailing the solution**

I’m outlining the process: updating CSS for Approach box borders, suggesting both minimal patch and variable unification, and ensuring backward compatibility and future-proofing with citation and version updates.
